modsecurity.transaction_messages_details.description:

modsecurity.transaction_messages_message.description:

modsecurity.transaction_response_headers.description:

network.application.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

When a specific application or service is identified from network connection details (source/dest IPs, ports, certificates, or wire format), this field captures the application's or service's name.
For example, the original event identifies the network connection being from a specific web service in a `https` network connection, like `facebook` or `twitter`.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

network.broadcast.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

Broadcast address.

network.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Total bytes transferred in both directions.
If `source.bytes` and `destination.bytes` are known, `network.bytes` is their sum.

network.community_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of source and destination IPs and ports, as well as the protocol used in a communication. This is a tool-agnostic standard to identify flows.
Learn more at https://github.com/corelight/community-id-spec.

network.dhcp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

DHCP status (enabled, disabled, unknown, BOOTP).

network.direction.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Direction of the network traffic.
When mapping events from a host-based monitoring context, populate this field from the host's point of view, using the values "ingress" or "egress".
When mapping events from a network or perimeter-based monitoring context, populate this field from the point of view of the network perimeter, using the values "inbound", "outbound", "internal" or "external".
Note that "internal" is not crossing perimeter boundaries, and is meant to describe communication between two hosts within the perimeter. Note also that "external" is meant to describe traffic between two hosts that are external to the perimeter. This could for example be useful for ISPs or VPN service providers.

network.forwarded_ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

Host IP address when the source IP address is the proxy.

network.gateway.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

Gateway address.

network.iana_number.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

IANA Protocol Number (https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml). Standardized list of protocols. This aligns well with NetFlow and sFlow related logs which use the IANA Protocol Number.

network.inner.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object

Network.inner fields are added in addition to network.vlan fields to describe the innermost VLAN when q-in-q VLAN tagging is present. Allowed fields include vlan.id and vlan.name. Inner vlan fields are typically used when sending traffic with multiple 802.1q encapsulations to a network sensor (e.g. Zeek, Wireshark.)

vlan.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

vlan.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Metric of the network protocol.

network.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name given by operators to sections of their network.

network.netmask.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

Network mask

network.packets.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Total packets transferred in both directions.
If `source.packets` and `destination.packets` are known, `network.packets` is their sum.

network.protocol.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

In the OSI Model this would be the Application Layer protocol. For example, `http`, `dns`, or `ssh`.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

network.transport.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Same as network.iana_number, but instead using the Keyword name of the transport layer (udp, tcp, ipv6-icmp, etc.)
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

network.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

Module: ecs

Observer.ingress holds information like interface number and name, vlan, and zone information to classify ingress traffic.  Single armed monitoring such as a network sensor on a span port should only use observer.ingress to categorize traffic.

interface.alias.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Interface alias as reported by the system, typically used in firewall implementations for e.g. inside, outside, or dmz logical interface naming.

interface.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Interface ID as reported by an observer (typically SNMP interface ID).

interface.mtu.description:
Module: ecs

Maximum transmission unit size.

Interface name as reported by the system.

observer.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

IP addresses of the observer.

observer.mac.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

MAC addresses of the observer.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

observer.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Custom name of the observer.
This is a name that can be given to an observer. This can be helpful for example if multiple firewalls of the same model are used in an organization.
If no custom name is needed, the field can be left empty.

observer.os.family.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

observer.os.full.description:
Module: ecs

observer.os.kernel.description:
Module: ecs

Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

observer.os.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Operating system name, without the version.

observer.os.platform.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

observer.os.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

observer.os.version.description:
Module: ecs

Operating system version as a raw string.

observer.product.description:
Module: ecs

observer.serial_number.description:

Observer serial number.

The type of the observer the data is coming from.
There is no predefined list of observer types. Some examples are `forwarder`, `firewall`, `ids`, `ips`, `proxy`, `poller`, `sensor`, `APM server`.

observer.vendor.description:
Module: ecs

Vendor name of the observer.

observer.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Observer version.

oracle.weblogic.diagnostic_context_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A unique identifier used for correlating related log messages across different components and subsystems within a single request or transaction flow. This is essential for distributed tracing and debugging.

oracle.weblogic.machine_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The name of the physical or virtual machine where the WebLogic server instance is running. This is useful in clustered environments to identify which node generated the log entry.

oracle.weblogic.message_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A unique identifier for the specific type of message or event being logged. WebLogic uses it to categorize different types of entries.

oracle.weblogic.meta.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Additional metadata or context information associated with the log entry. This may contain supplementary details about the logged event or operation.

oracle.weblogic.server_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The name of the WebLogic server instance that generated the log message. In a WebLogic domain, this could be an Admin Server or a Managed Server name (e.g., AdminServer, ManagedServer1, etc.).

oracle.weblogic.subsystem.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The WebLogic subsystem that generated the log message. Examples include Security, JTA (Java Transaction API), JDBC, JMS, EJB, HTTP, etc. This helps categorize log entries by functional area within the WebLogic server.

oracle.weblogic.thread_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The identifier of the thread that generated the log message. WebLogic uses thread pools to handle requests, and this field helps track which thread was responsible for the logged operation.

oracle.weblogic.transaction_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The identifier of the transaction associated with the log entry. In WebLogic, this helps track operations that span multiple components or services within a single business transaction.

API version being used to carry out the action

orchestrator.cluster.name.description:

orchestrator.cluster.url.description:

orchestrator.cluster.version.description:

orchestrator.namespace.description:

Namespace in which the action is taking place.

orchestrator.organization.description:

Organization affected by the event (for multi-tenant orchestrator setups).

orchestrator.resource.annotation.description:

The list of annotations added to the resource.

orchestrator.resource.id.description:

Unique ID of the resource being acted upon.

Module: ecs

orchestrator.resource.name.description:

Name of the resource being acted upon.

Module: ecs

Type of resource being acted upon.

orchestrator.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Orchestrator cluster type (e.g. kubernetes, nomad or cloudfoundry).

organization.id.description:
Module: ecs

Unique identifier for the organization.

organization.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Organization name.

package.architecture.description:
Module: ecs

Package architecture.

Additional information about the build version of the installed package.

package.checksum.description:
Module: ecs

Checksum of the installed package for verification.

package.description.description:
Module: ecs

Description of the package.

package.install_scope.description:
Module: ecs

Indicating how the package was installed, e.g. user-local, global.

package.installed.description:

package.name.description:
Module: ecs

Package name

package.path.description:

Path where the package is installed.

package.reference.description:
Module: ecs

Home page or reference URL of the software in this package, if available.

Package size in bytes.

Type of package.

process.code_signature.flags.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The flags used to sign the process.

process.code_signature.signing_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The identifier used to sign the process.

process.code_signature.status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

process.code_signature.team_id.description:

process.code_signature.thumbprint_sha256.description:

process.code_signature.timestamp.description:
Module: ecs

process.code_signature.trusted.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

A hash of the Go language imports in an ELF file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

Module: ecs

The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

Module: ecs

process.entry_leader.group.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the group.

process.entry_leader.interactive.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.
Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

process.entry_leader.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

process.entry_leader.parent.vpid.description:

Module: ecs

Process id.

process.entry_leader.real_group.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

process.entry_leader.real_group.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

process.entry_leader.real_user.id.description:
Module: ecs

process.entry_leader.real_user.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Short name or login of the user.

process.entry_leader.same_as_process.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

process.entry_leader.saved_group.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

process.entry_leader.saved_group.name.description:

Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

process.entry_leader.saved_user.name.description:
Module: ecs

Name of the group.

char_device.major.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The major number identifies the driver associated with the device. The character device's major and minor numbers can be algorithmically combined to produce the more familiar terminal identifiers such as "ttyS0" and "pts/0". For more details, please refer to the Linux kernel documentation.

char_device.minor.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The minor number is used only by the driver specified by the major number; other parts of the kernel dont use it, and merely pass it along to the driver. It is common for a driver to control several devices; the minor number provides a way for the driver to differentiate among them.

Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

process.io.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object

A chunk of input or output (IO) from a single process.
This field only appears on the top level process object, which is the process that wrote the output or read the input.

bytes_skipped.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object

An array of byte offsets and lengths denoting where IO data has been skipped.

length.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The length of bytes skipped.

offset.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The byte offset into this event's io.text (or io.bytes in the future) where length bytes were skipped.

max_bytes_per_process_exceeded.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

If true, the process producing the output has exceeded the max_kilobytes_per_process configuration setting.

text.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A chunk of output or input sanitized to UTF-8.
Best efforts are made to ensure complete lines are captured in these events. Assumptions should NOT be made that multiple lines will appear in the same event. TTY output may contain terminal control codes such as for cursor movement, so some string queries may not match due to terminal codes inserted between characters of a word.

total_bytes_captured.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The total number of bytes captured in this event.

total_bytes_skipped.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The total number of bytes that were not captured due to implementation restrictions such as buffer size limits. Implementors should strive to ensure this value is always zero

type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The type of object on which the IO action (read or write) was taken.
Currently only 'tty' is supported. Other types may be added in the future for 'file' and 'socket' support.

process.macho.go_import_hash.description:

A hash of the Go language imports in a Mach-O file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

process.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

process.parent.args.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

process.parent.args_count.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

process.parent.code_signature.digest_alg.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The hashing algorithm used to sign the process.
This value can distinguish signatures when a file is signed multiple times by the same signer but with a different digest algorithm.

process.parent.code_signature.exists.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

process.parent.code_signature.flags.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The flags used to sign the process.

process.parent.code_signature.signing_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

process.parent.code_signature.status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

process.parent.code_signature.subject_na.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Subject name of the code signer

process.parent.code_signature.team_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

process.parent.code_signature.thumbprint.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Certificate SHA256 hash that uniquely identifies the code signer.

process.parent.code_signature.timestamp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Date and time when the code signature was generated and signed.

process.parent.code_signature.trusted.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

process.parent.code_signature.valid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

process.parent.command_line.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

process.parent.elf.architecture.description:

Machine architecture of the ELF file.

process.parent.elf.byte_order.description:

Header type of the ELF file.

Module: ecs

Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

char_device.major.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The major number identifies the driver associated with the device. The character device's major and minor numbers can be algorithmically combined to produce the more familiar terminal identifiers such as "ttyS0" and "pts/0". For more details, please refer to the Linux kernel documentation.

char_device.minor.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The minor number is used only by the driver specified by the major number; other parts of the kernel dont use it, and merely pass it along to the driver. It is common for a driver to control several devices; the minor number provides a way for the driver to differentiate among them.

process.pe.go_import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the Go language imports in a PE file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

process.pe.go_imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of imported Go language element names and types.

process.pe.go_imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

process.pe.go_imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

process.pe.go_stripped.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

process.pe.imphash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

process.pe.import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the imports in a PE file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is a synonym for imphash.

process.pe.imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of imported element names and types.

process.pe.imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

process.pe.imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

process.pe.original_file_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

process.pe.pehash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the PE header and data from one or more PE sections. An pehash can be used to cluster files by transforming structural information about a file into a hash value.
Learn more at https://www.usenix.org/legacy/events/leet09/tech/full_papers/wicherski/wicherski_html/index.html.

process.pe.product.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

process.pe.sections.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: nested

An array containing an object for each section of the PE file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `pe.sections.*`.

entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

PE Section List name.

physical_size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

PE Section List physical size.

var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

virtual_size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

PE Section List virtual size. This is always the same as `physical_size`.

process.saved_user.name.description:

process.session_leader.args.description:

Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.

process.session_leader.args_count.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

process.session_leader.command_line.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

process.session_leader.entity_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

process.session_leader.executable.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Absolute path to the process executable.

process.session_leader.group.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

process.session_leader.group.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the group.

process.session_leader.interactive.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.
Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

process.session_leader.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

process.session_leader.parent.entity_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

process.session_leader.parent.pid.description:

process.session_leader.parent.session_le.description:
Module: ecs

Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

Module: ecs

Module: ecs

The time the process started.

process.session_leader.parent.vpid.description:

Module: ecs

Process id.

process.session_leader.real_group.name.description:

process.session_leader.real_user.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Short name or login of the user.

process.session_leader.same_as_process.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

process.session_leader.saved_group.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

process.session_leader.saved_group.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the group.

process.session_leader.saved_user.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier of the user.

process.session_leader.saved_user.name.description:

Short name or login of the user.

process.session_leader.supplemental_grou.description:

Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

Name of the group.

Module: ecs

Information about the controlling TTY device. If set, the process belongs to an interactive session.

char_device.major.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The major number identifies the driver associated with the device. The character device's major and minor numbers can be algorithmically combined to produce the more familiar terminal identifiers such as "ttyS0" and "pts/0". For more details, please refer to the Linux kernel documentation.

char_device.minor.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The minor number is used only by the driver specified by the major number; other parts of the kernel dont use it, and merely pass it along to the driver. It is common for a driver to control several devices; the minor number provides a way for the driver to differentiate among them.

Virtual process id.

Module: ecs

The working directory of the process.

char_device.major.description:
Module: ecs

The major number identifies the driver associated with the device. The character device's major and minor numbers can be algorithmically combined to produce the more familiar terminal identifiers such as "ttyS0" and "pts/0". For more details, please refer to the Linux kernel documentation.

char_device.minor.description:
Module: ecs

The minor number is used only by the driver specified by the major number; other parts of the kernel dont use it, and merely pass it along to the driver. It is common for a driver to control several devices; the minor number provides a way for the driver to differentiate among them.

columns.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The number of character columns per line. e.g terminal width
Terminal sizes can change, so this value reflects the maximum value for a given IO event. i.e. where event.action = 'text_output'

rows.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The number of character rows in the terminal. e.g terminal height
Terminal sizes can change, so this value reflects the maximum value for a given IO event. i.e. where event.action = 'text_output'

process.uptime.description:
Module: ecs

Seconds the process has been up.

process.user.id.description:
Module: ecs

Unique identifier of the user.

process.user.name.description:
Module: ecs

Short name or login of the user.

process.vpid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Virtual process id.
The process id within a pid namespace. This is not necessarily unique across all processes on the host but it is unique within the process namespace that the process exists within.

process.working_directory.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The working directory of the process.

registry.data.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Original bytes written with base64 encoding.
For Windows registry operations, such as SetValueEx and RegQueryValueEx, this corresponds to the data pointed by `lp_data`. This is optional but provides better recoverability and should be populated for REG_BINARY encoded values.

registry.data.strings.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Content when writing string types.
Populated as an array when writing string data to the registry. For single string registry types (REG_SZ, REG_EXPAND_SZ), this should be an array with one string. For sequences of string with REG_MULTI_SZ, this array will be variable length. For numeric data, such as REG_DWORD and REG_QWORD, this should be populated with the decimal representation (e.g `"1"`).

registry.data.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Standard registry type for encoding contents

registry.hive.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Abbreviated name for the hive.

registry.key.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Hive-relative path of keys.

registry.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Full path, including hive, key and value

registry.value.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the value written.

related.hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

All the hashes seen on your event. Populating this field, then using it to search for hashes can help in situations where you're unsure what the hash algorithm is (and therefore which key name to search).

related.hosts.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

All hostnames or other host identifiers seen on your event. Example identifiers include FQDNs, domain names, workstation names, or aliases.

related.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

All of the IPs seen on your event.

related.user.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

All the user names or other user identifiers seen on the event.

rule.author.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name, organization, or pseudonym of the author or authors who created the rule used to generate this event.

rule.category.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A categorization value keyword used by the entity using the rule for detection of this event.

rule.description.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The description of the rule generating the event.

rule.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A rule ID that is unique within the scope of an agent, observer, or other entity using the rule for detection of this event.

rule.license.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the license under which the rule used to generate this event is made available.

rule.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The name of the rule or signature generating the event.

rule.reference.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Reference URL to additional information about the rule used to generate this event.
The URL can point to the vendor's documentation about the rule. If that's not available, it can also be a link to a more general page describing this type of alert.

rule.ruleset.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the ruleset, policy, group, or parent category in which the rule used to generate this event is a member.

rule.uuid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A rule ID that is unique within the scope of a set or group of agents, observers, or other entities using the rule for detection of this event.

rule.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The version / revision of the rule being used for analysis.

server.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Some event server addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.

server.as.number.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

server.as.organization.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Organization name.

server.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Bytes sent from the server to the client.

server.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The domain name of the server system.
This value may be a host name, a fully qualified domain name, or another host naming format. The value may derive from the original event or be added from enrichment.

server.geo.city_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

City name.

server.geo.continent_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Two-letter code representing continent's name.

server.geo.continent_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the continent.

server.geo.country_iso_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Country ISO code.

server.geo.country_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Country name.

server.geo.location.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: geo_point

Longitude and latitude.

server.geo.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

server.geo.postal_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

server.geo.region_iso_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Region ISO code.

server.geo.region_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Region name.

server.geo.timezone.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

server.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

IP address of the server (IPv4 or IPv6).

server.mac.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

MAC address of the server.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

server.nat.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

Translated ip of destination based NAT sessions (e.g. internet to private DMZ)
Typically used with load balancers, firewalls, or routers.

server.nat.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Translated port of destination based NAT sessions (e.g. internet to private DMZ)
Typically used with load balancers, firewalls, or routers.

server.packets.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Packets sent from the server to the client.

server.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Port of the server.

server.registered_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The highest registered server domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

server.subdomain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

server.top_level_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

server.user.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

server.user.email.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

User email address.

server.user.full_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

User's full name, if available.

server.user.group.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the directory the group is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

server.user.group.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

server.user.group.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the group.

server.user.hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.

server.user.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier of the user.

server.user.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Short name or login of the user.

server.user.roles.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Array of user roles at the time of the event.

service.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Address where data about this service was collected from.
This should be a URI, network address (ipv4:port or [ipv6]:port) or a resource path (sockets).

service.environment.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Identifies the environment where the service is running.
If the same service runs in different environments (production, staging, QA, development, etc.), the environment can identify other instances of the same service. Can also group services and applications from the same environment.

service.ephemeral_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Ephemeral identifier of this service (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `service.id` does not.

service.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier of the running service. If the service is comprised of many nodes, the `service.id` should be the same for all nodes.
This id should uniquely identify the service. This makes it possible to correlate logs and metrics for one specific service, no matter which particular node emitted the event.
Note that if you need to see the events from one specific host of the service, you should filter on that `host.name` or `host.id` instead.

service.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the service data is collected from.
The name of the service is normally user given. This allows for distributed services that run on multiple hosts to correlate the related instances based on the name.
In the case of Elasticsearch the `service.name` could contain the cluster name. For Beats the `service.name` is by default a copy of the `service.type` field if no name is specified.

service.node.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of a service node.
This allows for two nodes of the same service running on the same host to be differentiated. Therefore, `service.node.name` should typically be unique across nodes of a given service.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.name` could contain the unique node name within the Elasticsearch cluster. In cases where the service doesn't have the concept of a node name, the host name or container name can be used to distinguish running instances that make up this service. If those do not provide uniqueness (e.g. multiple instances of the service running on the same host) - the node name can be manually set.

service.node.role.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Deprecated for removal in next major version release. This field will be superseded by `node.roles`.
Role of a service node.
This allows for distinction between different running roles of the same service.
In the case of Kibana, the `service.node.role` could be `ui` or `background_tasks`.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.role` could be `master` or `data`.
Other services could use this to distinguish between a `web` and `worker` role running as part of the service.

service.node.roles.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Roles of a service node.
This allows for distinction between different running roles of the same service.
In the case of Kibana, the `service.node.role` could be `ui` or `background_tasks` or both.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.role` could be `master` or `data` or both.
Other services could use this to distinguish between a `web` and `worker` role running as part of the service.

service.origin.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Address where data about this service was collected from.
This should be a URI, network address (ipv4:port or [ipv6]:port) or a resource path (sockets).

service.origin.environment.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Identifies the environment where the service is running.
If the same service runs in different environments (production, staging, QA, development, etc.), the environment can identify other instances of the same service. Can also group services and applications from the same environment.

service.origin.ephemeral_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Ephemeral identifier of this service (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `service.id` does not.

service.origin.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier of the running service. If the service is comprised of many nodes, the `service.id` should be the same for all nodes.
This id should uniquely identify the service. This makes it possible to correlate logs and metrics for one specific service, no matter which particular node emitted the event.
Note that if you need to see the events from one specific host of the service, you should filter on that `host.name` or `host.id` instead.

service.origin.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the service data is collected from.
The name of the service is normally user given. This allows for distributed services that run on multiple hosts to correlate the related instances based on the name.
In the case of Elasticsearch the `service.name` could contain the cluster name. For Beats the `service.name` is by default a copy of the `service.type` field if no name is specified.

service.origin.node.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of a service node.
This allows for two nodes of the same service running on the same host to be differentiated. Therefore, `service.node.name` should typically be unique across nodes of a given service.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.name` could contain the unique node name within the Elasticsearch cluster. In cases where the service doesn't have the concept of a node name, the host name or container name can be used to distinguish running instances that make up this service. If those do not provide uniqueness (e.g. multiple instances of the service running on the same host) - the node name can be manually set.

service.origin.node.role.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Deprecated for removal in next major version release. This field will be superseded by `node.roles`.
Role of a service node.
This allows for distinction between different running roles of the same service.
In the case of Kibana, the `service.node.role` could be `ui` or `background_tasks`.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.role` could be `master` or `data`.
Other services could use this to distinguish between a `web` and `worker` role running as part of the service.

service.origin.node.roles.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Roles of a service node.
This allows for distinction between different running roles of the same service.
In the case of Kibana, the `service.node.role` could be `ui` or `background_tasks` or both.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.role` could be `master` or `data` or both.
Other services could use this to distinguish between a `web` and `worker` role running as part of the service.

service.origin.state.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Current state of the service.

service.origin.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The type of the service data is collected from.
The type can be used to group and correlate logs and metrics from one service type.
Example: If logs or metrics are collected from Elasticsearch, `service.type` would be `elasticsearch`.

service.origin.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Version of the service the data was collected from.
This allows to look at a data set only for a specific version of a service.

service.state.description:
Module: ecs

Current state of the service.

sonicwall.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object

An object containing specific events and data captured by SonicWall firewall devices.

firewall.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object

An object containing SonicWall firewall-specific fields extracted from log events.

af_polid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The application firewall policy ID from SonicWall logs, identifying the specific application firewall policy applied to the traffic.

app.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The application ID from SonicWall firewall logs, indicating the specific application or service detected in the network traffic.

app_cat.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The application category from SonicWall Application Intelligence and Control (AIC), providing classification of the detected application.

app_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Alternative application identifier used in SonicWall logs for application detection and control.

app_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The human-readable name of the detected application from SonicWall Application Intelligence and Control (AIC).

audit_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The audit event identifier from SonicWall logs, used for tracking administrative actions and configuration changes.

category.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The web content category from SonicWall Content Filter Service (CFS), indicating the classification of web content (e.g., "Not Rated", "Freeware/Software Downloads", "Search Engines and Portals").

code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The response or action code from SonicWall firewall logs, providing additional context about the event outcome or classification.

dpi.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) status indicating whether advanced packet inspection was performed on the traffic.

event_group_category.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The event group category mapped from the gcat field, providing a human-readable classification of the event type (e.g., "gateway-av", "authentication", "content-filter").

gcat.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The global category identifier from SonicWall logs, used to classify different types of security events and policies.

ips_cat.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) category from SonicWall, indicating the type of threat or attack pattern detected.

old_value.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The previous value in configuration change events, used in audit logs to track what was modified.

sess.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The session type from SonicWall firewall logs, indicating the type of management or user session (e.g., "Web", "SSH", "Console").

tranx_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The transaction identifier from SonicWall logs, used to correlate related events and track security transactions.

type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The event type identifier from SonicWall logs, providing additional classification of the security event.

user_mode.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The user authentication mode from SonicWall logs, indicating how the user was authenticated or identified.

uuid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The universally unique identifier (UUID) from SonicWall logs, used to uniquely identify specific events or configurations.

source.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Some event source addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.

source.as.number.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

source.as.organization.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Organization name.

source.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Bytes sent from the source to the destination.

source.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The domain name of the source system.
This value may be a host name, a fully qualified domain name, or another host naming format. The value may derive from the original event or be added from enrichment.

source.geo.city_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

City name.

source.geo.continent_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Two-letter code representing continent's name.

source.geo.continent_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the continent.

source.geo.country_iso_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Country ISO code.

source.geo.country_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Country name.

source.geo.location.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: geo_point

Longitude and latitude.

source.geo.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

source.geo.postal_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

source.geo.region_iso_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Region ISO code.

source.geo.region_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Region name.

source.geo.timezone.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

source.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

IP address of the source (IPv4 or IPv6).

source.mac.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

MAC address of the source.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

source.nat.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

Translated ip of source based NAT sessions (e.g. internal client to internet)
Typically connections traversing load balancers, firewalls, or routers.

source.nat.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Translated port of source based NAT sessions. (e.g. internal client to internet)
Typically used with load balancers, firewalls, or routers.

source.packets.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Packets sent from the source to the destination.

source.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Port of the source.

source.registered_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The highest registered source domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

source.subdomain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

source.top_level_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

source.user.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

source.user.email.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

User email address.

source.user.full_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

User's full name, if available.

source.user.group.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the directory the group is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

source.user.group.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

source.user.group.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the group.

source.user.hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.

source.user.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier of the user.

source.user.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Short name or login of the user.

source.user.roles.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Array of user roles at the time of the event.

span.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier of the span within the scope of its trace.
A span represents an operation within a transaction, such as a request to another service, or a database query.

sysmon.dns.status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

DNS query status from Sysmon DNS events

sysmon.file.archived.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Whether file was archived from Sysmon file deletion events

sysmon.file.is_executable.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Whether file is executable from Sysmon file events

threat.enrichments.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: nested

A list of associated indicators objects enriching the event, and the context of that association/enrichment.

indicator.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object

Object containing associated indicators enriching the event.

as.number.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

as.organization.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Organization name.

confidence.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Identifies the vendor-neutral confidence rating using the None/Low/Medium/High scale defined in Appendix A of the STIX 2.1 framework. Vendor-specific confidence scales may be added as custom fields.

description.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Describes the type of action conducted by the threat.

email.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Identifies a threat indicator as an email address (irrespective of direction).

file.accessed.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Last time the file was accessed.
Note that not all filesystems keep track of access time.

file.attributes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Array of file attributes.
Attributes names will vary by platform. Here's a non-exhaustive list of values that are expected in this field: archive, compressed, directory, encrypted, execute, hidden, read, readonly, system, write.

file.code_signature.digest_algorithm.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The hashing algorithm used to sign the process.
This value can distinguish signatures when a file is signed multiple times by the same signer but with a different digest algorithm.

file.code_signature.exists.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

file.code_signature.flags.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The flags used to sign the process.

file.code_signature.signing_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

file.code_signature.status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

file.code_signature.subject_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Subject name of the code signer

file.code_signature.team_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

file.code_signature.thumbprint_sha256.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Certificate SHA256 hash that uniquely identifies the code signer.

file.code_signature.timestamp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Date and time when the code signature was generated and signed.

file.code_signature.trusted.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

file.code_signature.valid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

file.created.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

File creation time.
Note that not all filesystems store the creation time.

file.ctime.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Last time the file attributes or metadata changed.
Note that changes to the file content will update `mtime`. This implies `ctime` will be adjusted at the same time, since `mtime` is an attribute of the file.

file.device.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Device that is the source of the file.

file.directory.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

file.drive_letter.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Drive letter where the file is located. This field is only relevant on Windows.
The value should be uppercase, and not include the colon.

file.elf.architecture.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Machine architecture of the ELF file.

file.elf.byte_order.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Byte sequence of ELF file.

file.elf.cpu_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

CPU type of the ELF file.

file.elf.creation_date.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Extracted when possible from the file's metadata. Indicates when it was built or compiled. It can also be faked by malware creators.

file.elf.exports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of exported element names and types.

file.elf.go_import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the Go language imports in an ELF file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

file.elf.go_imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of imported Go language element names and types.

file.elf.go_imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

file.elf.go_imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

file.elf.go_stripped.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

file.elf.header.abi_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Version of the ELF Application Binary Interface (ABI).

file.elf.header.class.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Header class of the ELF file.

file.elf.header.data.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Data table of the ELF header.

file.elf.header.entrypoint.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Header entrypoint of the ELF file.

file.elf.header.object_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

"0x1" for original ELF files.

file.elf.header.os_abi.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Application Binary Interface (ABI) of the Linux OS.

file.elf.header.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Header type of the ELF file.

file.elf.header.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Version of the ELF header.

file.elf.import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the imports in an ELF file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is an ELF implementation of the Windows PE imphash.

file.elf.imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of imported element names and types.

file.elf.imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

file.elf.imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

file.elf.sections.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: nested

An array containing an object for each section of the ELF file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `elf.sections.*`.

chi2.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Chi-square probability distribution of the section.

entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

flags.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

ELF Section List flags.

name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

ELF Section List name.

physical_offset.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

ELF Section List offset.

physical_size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

ELF Section List physical size.

type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

ELF Section List type.

var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

virtual_address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

ELF Section List virtual address.

virtual_size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

ELF Section List virtual size.

file.elf.segments.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: nested

An array containing an object for each segment of the ELF file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `elf.segments.*`.

sections.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

ELF object segment sections.

type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

ELF object segment type.

file.elf.shared_libraries.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

List of shared libraries used by this ELF object.

file.elf.telfhash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

telfhash symbol hash for ELF file.

file.extension.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

File extension, excluding the leading dot.
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

file.fork_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A fork is additional data associated with a filesystem object.
On Linux, a resource fork is used to store additional data with a filesystem object. A file always has at least one fork for the data portion, and additional forks may exist.
On NTFS, this is analogous to an Alternate Data Stream (ADS), and the default data stream for a file is just called $DATA. Zone.Identifier is commonly used by Windows to track contents downloaded from the Internet. An ADS is typically of the form: `C:\path\to\filename.extension:some_fork_name`, and `some_fork_name` is the value that should populate `fork_name`. `filename.extension` should populate `file.name`, and `extension` should populate `file.extension`. The full path, `file.path`, will include the fork name.

file.gid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

file.group.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Primary group name of the file.

file.hash.cdhash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Code directory hash, utilized to uniquely identify and authenticate the integrity of the executable code.

file.hash.md5.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

MD5 hash.

file.hash.sha1.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SHA1 hash.

file.hash.sha256.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SHA256 hash.

file.hash.sha384.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SHA384 hash.

file.hash.sha512.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SHA512 hash.

file.hash.ssdeep.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SSDEEP hash.

file.hash.tlsh.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

TLSH hash.

file.inode.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

file.mime_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

MIME type should identify the format of the file or stream of bytes using IANA official types: https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml, where possible. When more than one type is applicable, the most specific type should be used.

file.mode.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Mode of the file in octal representation.

file.mtime.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Last time the file content was modified.

file.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

file.origin_referrer_url.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The URL of the webpage that linked to the file.

file.origin_url.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The URL where the file is hosted.

file.owner.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

File owner's username.

file.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Full path to the file, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

file.pe.architecture.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

CPU architecture target for the file.

file.pe.company.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

file.pe.description.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

file.pe.file_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

file.pe.go_import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the Go language imports in a PE file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

file.pe.go_imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of imported Go language element names and types.

file.pe.go_imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

file.pe.go_imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

file.pe.go_stripped.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

file.pe.imphash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

file.pe.import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the imports in a PE file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is a synonym for imphash.

file.pe.imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of imported element names and types.

file.pe.imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

file.pe.imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

file.pe.original_file_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

file.pe.pehash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the PE header and data from one or more PE sections. An pehash can be used to cluster files by transforming structural information about a file into a hash value.
Learn more at https://www.usenix.org/legacy/events/leet09/tech/full_papers/wicherski/wicherski_html/index.html.

file.pe.product.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

file.pe.sections.description:
Module: ecs

An array containing an object for each section of the PE file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `pe.sections.*`.

entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

name.description:

PE Section List name.

physical_size.description:

PE Section List physical size.

var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

virtual_size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

PE Section List virtual size. This is always the same as `physical_size`.

file.size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

File size in bytes.
Only relevant when `file.type` is "file".

file.type.description:

File type (file, dir, or symlink).

file.uid.description:

The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

Distinguished name (DN) of the certificate subject entity.

file.x509.subject.locality.description:
Module: ecs

List of locality names (L)

file.x509.subject.organization.description:
Module: ecs

List of organizations (O) of subject.

file.x509.subject.organizational_unit.description:
Module: ecs
