Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

Module: ecs

Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

marking.tlp.description:

marking.tlp_version.description:

URL, IP address, email address, registry key, port number, hash value, or other relevant name can serve as the display name.

Module: ecs

Identifies a threat indicator as a port number (irrespective of direction).

provider.description:
Module: ecs

The name of the indicator's provider.

reference.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Reference URL linking to additional information about this indicator.

registry.data.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Original bytes written with base64 encoding.
For Windows registry operations, such as SetValueEx and RegQueryValueEx, this corresponds to the data pointed by `lp_data`. This is optional but provides better recoverability and should be populated for REG_BINARY encoded values.

registry.data.strings.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Content when writing string types.
Populated as an array when writing string data to the registry. For single string registry types (REG_SZ, REG_EXPAND_SZ), this should be an array with one string. For sequences of string with REG_MULTI_SZ, this array will be variable length. For numeric data, such as REG_DWORD and REG_QWORD, this should be populated with the decimal representation (e.g `"1"`).

registry.data.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Standard registry type for encoding contents

registry.hive.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Abbreviated name for the hive.

registry.key.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Hive-relative path of keys.

registry.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Full path, including hive, key and value

registry.value.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the value written.

scanner_stats.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Count of AV/EDR vendors that successfully detected malicious file or URL.

sightings.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Number of times this indicator was observed conducting threat activity.

type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Type of indicator as represented by Cyber Observable in STIX 2.0.

url.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Domain of the url, such as "www.elastic.co".
In some cases a URL may refer to an IP and/or port directly, without a domain name. In this case, the IP address would go to the `domain` field.
If the URL contains a literal IPv6 address enclosed by `[` and `]` (IETF RFC 2732), the `[` and `]` characters should also be captured in the `domain` field.

url.extension.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The field contains the file extension from the original request url, excluding the leading dot.
The file extension is only set if it exists, as not every url has a file extension.
The leading period must not be included. For example, the value must be "png", not ".png".
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

url.fragment.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Portion of the url after the `#`, such as "top".
The `#` is not part of the fragment.

url.full.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

If full URLs are important to your use case, they should be stored in `url.full`, whether this field is reconstructed or present in the event source.

url.original.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.
Note that in network monitoring, the observed URL may be a full URL, whereas in access logs, the URL is often just represented as a path.
This field is meant to represent the URL as it was observed, complete or not.

url.password.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Password of the request.

url.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Path of the request, such as "/search".

url.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Port of the request, such as 443.

url.query.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The query field describes the query string of the request, such as "q=elasticsearch".
The `?` is excluded from the query string. If a URL contains no `?`, there is no query field. If there is a `?` but no query, the query field exists with an empty string. The `exists` query can be used to differentiate between the two cases.

url.registered_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The highest registered url domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

url.scheme.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Scheme of the request, such as "https".
Note: The `:` is not part of the scheme.

url.subdomain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

url.top_level_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

url.username.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Username of the request.

List of subject alternative names (SAN). Name types vary by certificate authority and certificate type but commonly contain IP addresses, DNS names (and wildcards), and email addresses.

Identifier for certificate signature algorithm. We recommend using names found in Go Lang Crypto library. See https://github.com/golang/go/blob/go1.14/src/crypto/x509/x509.go#L337-L353.

threat.feed.dashboard_id.description:

The saved object ID of the dashboard belonging to the threat feed for displaying dashboard links to threat feeds in Kibana.

The name of the threat feed in UI friendly format.

Name of the threat framework used to further categorize and classify the tactic and technique of the reported threat. Framework classification can be provided by detecting systems, evaluated at ingest time, or retrospectively tagged to events.

threat.group.alias.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The alias(es) of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK group alias(es).

threat.group.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The id of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK group id.

threat.group.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The name of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK group name.

threat.group.reference.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK group reference URL.

threat.indicator.as.number.description:
Module: ecs

Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

threat.indicator.as.organization.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Organization name.

threat.indicator.confidence.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Identifies the vendor-neutral confidence rating using the None/Low/Medium/High scale defined in Appendix A of the STIX 2.1 framework. Vendor-specific confidence scales may be added as custom fields.

threat.indicator.description.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Describes the type of action conducted by the threat.

threat.indicator.email.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Identifies a threat indicator as an email address (irrespective of direction).

threat.indicator.file.accessed.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Last time the file was accessed.
Note that not all filesystems keep track of access time.

threat.indicator.file.attributes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Array of file attributes.
Attributes names will vary by platform. Here's a non-exhaustive list of values that are expected in this field: archive, compressed, directory, encrypted, execute, hidden, read, readonly, system, write.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.dig.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The hashing algorithm used to sign the process.
This value can distinguish signatures when a file is signed multiple times by the same signer but with a different digest algorithm.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.exi.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.fla.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The flags used to sign the process.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.sig.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.sta.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.sub.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Subject name of the code signer

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.tea.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.thu.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Certificate SHA256 hash that uniquely identifies the code signer.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.tim.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Date and time when the code signature was generated and signed.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.tru.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

threat.indicator.file.code_signature.val.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

threat.indicator.file.created.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

File creation time.
Note that not all filesystems store the creation time.

threat.indicator.file.ctime.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

Last time the file attributes or metadata changed.
Note that changes to the file content will update `mtime`. This implies `ctime` will be adjusted at the same time, since `mtime` is an attribute of the file.

threat.indicator.file.device.description:

Device that is the source of the file.

threat.indicator.file.directory.description:
Module: ecs

Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

threat.indicator.file.drive_letter.description:
Module: ecs

Drive letter where the file is located. This field is only relevant on Windows.
The value should be uppercase, and not include the colon.

threat.indicator.file.elf.architecture.description:

threat.indicator.file.elf.byte_order.description:

threat.indicator.file.elf.cpu_type.description:

threat.indicator.file.elf.creation_date.description:

Extracted when possible from the file's metadata. Indicates when it was built or compiled. It can also be faked by malware creators.

threat.indicator.file.elf.go_import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the Go language imports in an ELF file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

threat.indicator.file.elf.go_imports.description:
Module: ecs

List of imported Go language element names and types.

Module: ecs

Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

Module: ecs

Header entrypoint of the ELF file.

Module: ecs

"0x1" for original ELF files.

threat.indicator.file.elf.header.os_abi.description:
Module: ecs

Application Binary Interface (ABI) of the Linux OS.

threat.indicator.file.elf.header.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Header type of the ELF file.

threat.indicator.file.elf.header.version.description:
Module: ecs

Version of the ELF header.

threat.indicator.file.elf.import_hash.description:

A hash of the imports in an ELF file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is an ELF implementation of the Windows PE imphash.

threat.indicator.file.elf.imports.description:
Module: ecs

threat.indicator.file.elf.imports_names_.description:
Module: ecs

Module: ecs

Module: ecs

Chi-square probability distribution of the section.

entropy.description:

threat.indicator.file.elf.segments.description:
Module: ecs

An array containing an object for each segment of the ELF file.

Module: ecs

ELF object segment sections.

type.description:
Module: ecs

ELF object segment type.

threat.indicator.file.elf.shared_librari.description:
Module: ecs

List of shared libraries used by this ELF object.

threat.indicator.file.elf.telfhash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

telfhash symbol hash for ELF file.

threat.indicator.file.extension.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

File extension, excluding the leading dot.
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

threat.indicator.file.fork_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A fork is additional data associated with a filesystem object.
On Linux, a resource fork is used to store additional data with a filesystem object. A file always has at least one fork for the data portion, and additional forks may exist.
On NTFS, this is analogous to an Alternate Data Stream (ADS), and the default data stream for a file is just called $DATA. Zone.Identifier is commonly used by Windows to track contents downloaded from the Internet. An ADS is typically of the form: `C:\path\to\filename.extension:some_fork_name`, and `some_fork_name` is the value that should populate `fork_name`. `filename.extension` should populate `file.name`, and `extension` should populate `file.extension`. The full path, `file.path`, will include the fork name.

threat.indicator.file.gid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

threat.indicator.file.group.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Primary group name of the file.

threat.indicator.file.hash.cdhash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Code directory hash, utilized to uniquely identify and authenticate the integrity of the executable code.

threat.indicator.file.hash.md5.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

MD5 hash.

threat.indicator.file.hash.sha1.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SHA1 hash.

threat.indicator.file.hash.sha256.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SHA256 hash.

threat.indicator.file.hash.sha384.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SHA384 hash.

threat.indicator.file.hash.sha512.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

threat.indicator.file.hash.ssdeep.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

SSDEEP hash.

threat.indicator.file.hash.tlsh.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

TLSH hash.

threat.indicator.file.inode.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

threat.indicator.file.mime_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

MIME type should identify the format of the file or stream of bytes using IANA official types: https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml, where possible. When more than one type is applicable, the most specific type should be used.

threat.indicator.file.mode.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Mode of the file in octal representation.

threat.indicator.file.mtime.description:
Module: ecs

threat.indicator.file.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

threat.indicator.file.origin_referrer_ur.description:
Module: ecs

The URL of the webpage that linked to the file.

threat.indicator.file.origin_url.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The URL where the file is hosted.

threat.indicator.file.owner.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

File owner's username.

threat.indicator.file.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Full path to the file, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

threat.indicator.file.pe.architecture.description:
Module: ecs

CPU architecture target for the file.

threat.indicator.file.pe.company.description:
Module: ecs

Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

threat.indicator.file.pe.description.description:
Module: ecs

Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

threat.indicator.file.pe.file_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

threat.indicator.file.pe.go_import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the Go language imports in a PE file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available here: https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma

threat.indicator.file.pe.go_imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of imported Go language element names and types.

threat.indicator.file.pe.go_imports_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

threat.indicator.file.pe.go_stripped.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

threat.indicator.file.pe.imphash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

threat.indicator.file.pe.import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the imports in a PE file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is a synonym for imphash.

threat.indicator.file.pe.imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: flat_object

List of imported element names and types.

threat.indicator.file.pe.imports_names_e.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

threat.indicator.file.pe.imports_names_v.description:

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

threat.indicator.file.pe.pehash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A hash of the PE header and data from one or more PE sections. An pehash can be used to cluster files by transforming structural information about a file into a hash value.
Learn more at https://www.usenix.org/legacy/events/leet09/tech/full_papers/wicherski/wicherski_html/index.html.

threat.indicator.file.pe.product.description:

threat.indicator.file.pe.sections.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: nested

An array containing an object for each section of the PE file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `pe.sections.*`.

entropy.description:
Module: ecs

Identifier for certificate signature algorithm. We recommend using names found in Go Lang Crypto library. See https://github.com/golang/go/blob/go1.14/src/crypto/x509/x509.go#L337-L353.

Module: ecs

threat.indicator.geo.city_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

City name.

threat.indicator.geo.continent_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Two-letter code representing continent's name.

threat.indicator.geo.continent_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the continent.

threat.indicator.geo.country_iso_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Country ISO code.

threat.indicator.geo.country_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Country name.

threat.indicator.geo.location.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: geo_point

Longitude and latitude.

threat.indicator.geo.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

threat.indicator.geo.postal_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

threat.indicator.geo.region_iso_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Region ISO code.

threat.indicator.geo.region_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Region name.

threat.indicator.geo.timezone.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

threat.indicator.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The ID of the indicator used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK. This field can have multiple values to allow for the identification of the same indicator across systems that use different ID formats.
While not required, a common approach is to use a STIX 2.x indicator ID.

threat.indicator.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

Identifies a threat indicator as an IP address (irrespective of direction).

threat.indicator.last_seen.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

The date and time when intelligence source last reported sighting this indicator.

threat.indicator.marking.tlp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Traffic Light Protocol sharing markings.

threat.indicator.marking.tlp_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Traffic Light Protocol version.

threat.indicator.modified_at.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

The date and time when intelligence source last modified information for this indicator.

threat.indicator.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The display name indicator in an UI friendly format
URL, IP address, email address, registry key, port number, hash value, or other relevant name can serve as the display name.

threat.indicator.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Identifies a threat indicator as a port number (irrespective of direction).

threat.indicator.provider.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The name of the indicator's provider.

threat.indicator.reference.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Reference URL linking to additional information about this indicator.

threat.indicator.registry.data.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Original bytes written with base64 encoding.
For Windows registry operations, such as SetValueEx and RegQueryValueEx, this corresponds to the data pointed by `lp_data`. This is optional but provides better recoverability and should be populated for REG_BINARY encoded values.

threat.indicator.registry.data.strings.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Content when writing string types.
Populated as an array when writing string data to the registry. For single string registry types (REG_SZ, REG_EXPAND_SZ), this should be an array with one string. For sequences of string with REG_MULTI_SZ, this array will be variable length. For numeric data, such as REG_DWORD and REG_QWORD, this should be populated with the decimal representation (e.g `"1"`).

threat.indicator.registry.data.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Standard registry type for encoding contents

threat.indicator.registry.hive.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Abbreviated name for the hive.

threat.indicator.registry.key.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Hive-relative path of keys.

threat.indicator.registry.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Full path, including hive, key and value

threat.indicator.registry.value.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Name of the value written.

threat.indicator.scanner_stats.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Count of AV/EDR vendors that successfully detected malicious file or URL.

threat.indicator.sightings.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Number of times this indicator was observed conducting threat activity.

threat.indicator.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Type of indicator as represented by Cyber Observable in STIX 2.0.

threat.indicator.url.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Domain of the url, such as "www.elastic.co".
In some cases a URL may refer to an IP and/or port directly, without a domain name. In this case, the IP address would go to the `domain` field.
If the URL contains a literal IPv6 address enclosed by `[` and `]` (IETF RFC 2732), the `[` and `]` characters should also be captured in the `domain` field.

threat.indicator.url.extension.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The field contains the file extension from the original request url, excluding the leading dot.
The file extension is only set if it exists, as not every url has a file extension.
The leading period must not be included. For example, the value must be "png", not ".png".
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

threat.indicator.url.fragment.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Portion of the url after the `#`, such as "top".
The `#` is not part of the fragment.

threat.indicator.url.full.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

If full URLs are important to your use case, they should be stored in `url.full`, whether this field is reconstructed or present in the event source.

threat.indicator.url.original.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.
Note that in network monitoring, the observed URL may be a full URL, whereas in access logs, the URL is often just represented as a path.
This field is meant to represent the URL as it was observed, complete or not.

threat.indicator.url.password.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Password of the request.

threat.indicator.url.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Path of the request, such as "/search".

threat.indicator.url.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Port of the request, such as 443.

threat.indicator.url.query.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The query field describes the query string of the request, such as "q=elasticsearch".
The `?` is excluded from the query string. If a URL contains no `?`, there is no query field. If there is a `?` but no query, the query field exists with an empty string. The `exists` query can be used to differentiate between the two cases.

threat.indicator.url.registered_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The highest registered url domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

threat.indicator.url.scheme.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Scheme of the request, such as "https".
Note: The `:` is not part of the scheme.

threat.indicator.url.subdomain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

threat.indicator.url.top_level_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

trace.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier of the trace.
A trace groups multiple events like transactions that belong together. For example, a user request handled by multiple inter-connected services.

transaction.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unique identifier of the transaction within the scope of its trace.
A transaction is the highest level of work measured within a service, such as a request to a server.

url.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Domain of the url, such as "www.elastic.co".
In some cases a URL may refer to an IP and/or port directly, without a domain name. In this case, the IP address would go to the `domain` field.
If the URL contains a literal IPv6 address enclosed by `[` and `]` (IETF RFC 2732), the `[` and `]` characters should also be captured in the `domain` field.

url.extension.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The field contains the file extension from the original request url, excluding the leading dot.
The file extension is only set if it exists, as not every url has a file extension.
The leading period must not be included. For example, the value must be "png", not ".png".
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

url.fragment.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Portion of the url after the `#`, such as "top".
The `#` is not part of the fragment.

url.full.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

If full URLs are important to your use case, they should be stored in `url.full`, whether this field is reconstructed or present in the event source.

url.original.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.
Note that in network monitoring, the observed URL may be a full URL, whereas in access logs, the URL is often just represented as a path.
This field is meant to represent the URL as it was observed, complete or not.

url.password.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Password of the request.

url.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Path of the request, such as "/search".

url.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Port of the request, such as 443.

url.query.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The query field describes the query string of the request, such as "q=elasticsearch".
The `?` is excluded from the query string. If a URL contains no `?`, there is no query field. If there is a `?` but no query, the query field exists with an empty string. The `exists` query can be used to differentiate between the two cases.

url.registered_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The highest registered url domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

url.scheme.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Scheme of the request, such as "https".
Note: The `:` is not part of the scheme.

url.subdomain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

url.top_level_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (https://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

url.username.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Username of the request.

volume.bus_type.description:

Bus type of the device, such as `Nvme`, `Usb`, or `FileBackedVirtual`.

volume.default_access.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Describes the default access(es) of the volume.

volume.device_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Full path of the volume device.
Only populate this field for POSIX system volumes.

volume.device_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Volume device type.
The most frequently seen volume device types are `Disk File System` and `CD-ROM File System`.

volume.dos_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The MS-DOS name of a device.
DOS device name is in the format of driver letters, such as `C:`. The field is relevant to Windows systems only.

volume.file_system_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Volume device file system type.
The most common volume file system types are `NTFS` and `UDF`.

volume.mount_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Mount name of the volume device.
Only populate this field for POSIX system volumes.

volume.nt_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The NT device name.
NT device name uses a format of `\Device\HarddiskVolume2`. The field is relevant to Windows systems only.

volume.product_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

ProductID of the device.
The vendor provides the ProductID for the volume, if any.

volume.product_name.description:

Product name of the volume.
The volume device vendor provides this value.

volume.removable.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Indicates if the volume is removable.

volume.serial_number.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Serial number identifier for the volume device.
The serial number is provided by the vendor of the device, if any.

volume.size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

Size of the volume device in bytes.

volume.vendor_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

VendorID of the volume device.
The volume device vendor provides this value.

volume.vendor_name.description:
Module: ecs

The value is provided by the vendor of the device.

volume.writable.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Indicates if the volume is writable.

vulnerability.category.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The type of system or architecture that the vulnerability affects. These may be platform-specific (for example, Debian or SUSE) or general (for example, Database or Firewall). For example (https://qualysguard.qualys.com/qwebhelp/fo_portal/knowledgebase/vulnerability_categories.htm)
This field must be an array.

vulnerability.classification.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The classification of the vulnerability scoring system. For example (https://www.first.org/cvss/)

vulnerability.description.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The description of the vulnerability that provides additional context of the vulnerability. For example (https://cve.mitre.org/about/faqs.html#cve_entry_descriptions_created)

vulnerability.enumeration.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The type of identifier used for this vulnerability. For example (https://cve.mitre.org/about/)

vulnerability.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The identification (ID) is the number portion of a vulnerability entry. It includes a unique identification number for the vulnerability. For example (https://cve.mitre.org/about/faqs.html#what_is_cve_id)

vulnerability.reference.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A resource that provides additional information, context, and mitigations for the identified vulnerability.

vulnerability.report_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The report or scan identification number.

vulnerability.scanner.reference.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Scanner's resource that provides additional information, context, and mitigations for the identified vulnerability.

vulnerability.scanner.vendor.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The name of the vulnerability scanner vendor.

vulnerability.score.base.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: float

Scores can range from 0.0 to 10.0, with 10.0 being the most severe.
Base scores cover an assessment for exploitability metrics (attack vector, complexity, privileges, and user interaction), impact metrics (confidentiality, integrity, and availability), and scope. For example (https://www.first.org/cvss/specification-document)

vulnerability.score.environmental.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: float

Scores can range from 0.0 to 10.0, with 10.0 being the most severe.
Environmental scores cover an assessment for any modified Base metrics, confidentiality, integrity, and availability requirements. For example (https://www.first.org/cvss/specification-document)

vulnerability.score.temporal.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: float

Scores can range from 0.0 to 10.0, with 10.0 being the most severe.
Temporal scores cover an assessment for code maturity, remediation level, and confidence. For example (https://www.first.org/cvss/specification-document)

vulnerability.score.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The National Vulnerability Database (NVD) provides qualitative severity rankings of "Low", "Medium", and "High" for CVSS v2.0 base score ranges in addition to the severity ratings for CVSS v3.0 as they are defined in the CVSS v3.0 specification.
CVSS is owned and managed by FIRST.Org, Inc. (FIRST), a US-based non-profit organization, whose mission is to help computer security incident response teams across the world. For example (https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln-metrics/cvss)

vulnerability.severity.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The severity of the vulnerability can help with metrics and internal prioritization regarding remediation. For example (https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln-metrics/cvss)

wazuh.agent.build.original.description:
Module: ecs

IndexerType: keyword

Linux boot uuid taken from /proc/sys/kernel/random/boot_id. Note the boot_id value from /proc may or may not be the same in containers as on the host. Some container runtimes will bind mount a new boot_id value onto the proc file in each container.

CPU Model name.

speed.description:
Module: ecs

CPU clock speed.

usage.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: scaled_float

Percent CPU used which is normalized by the number of CPU cores and it ranges from 0 to 1.
Scaling factor: 1000.
For example: For a two core host, this value should be the average of the two cores, between 0 and 1.

zeek.dhcp_agent_remote_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

A globally unique identifier added by relay agents to identify the remote host end of the circuit.

zeek.dhcp_assigned_addr.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the IP address assigned by the server.

zeek.dhcp_circuit_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Added by DHCP relay agents which terminate switched or permanent circuits. It encodes an agent-local identifier of the circuit from which a DHCP client-to-server packet was received. Typically it should represent a router or switch interface number.

zeek.dhcp_client_addr.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the IP address of the client. If a transaction is only a client sending INFORM messages then there is no lease information exchanged so this is helpful to know who sent the messages. Getting an address in this field does require that the client sources at least one DHCP message using a non-broadcast address.

zeek.dhcp_client_message.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the message typically accompanied with a DHCP_DECLINE so the client can tell the server why it rejected an address.

zeek.dhcp_client_software.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The software reported by the client in the vendor_class option.

zeek.dhcp_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the domain given by the server in option 15.

zeek.dhcp_duration.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the duration of the DHCP session representing the time from the first message to the last.

zeek.dhcp_host_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the name given by client in Hostname option 12.

zeek.dhcp_lease_time.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the IP address lease interval.

zeek.dhcp_mac.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the client's hardware address.

zeek.dhcp_msg_orig.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The address that originated each message from the msg_types field.

zeek.dhcp_msg_types.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The DHCP message types seen by this DHCP transaction.

zeek.dhcp_requested_addr.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the IP address requested by the client.

zeek.dhcp_server_addr.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the IP address of the server involved in actually handing out the lease. There could be other servers replying with OFFER messages which won't be represented here. Getting an address in this field also requires that the server handing out the lease also sources packets from a non-broadcast IP address.

zeek.dhcp_server_message.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Message typically accompanied with a DHCP_NAK to let the client know why it rejected the request.

zeek.dhcp_server_software.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the software reported by the server in the vendor_class option.

zeek.ntp_ref_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

For stratum 0, 4 character string used for debugging. For stratum 1, ID assigned to the reference clock by IANA. Above stratum 1, when using IPv4, the IP address of the reference clock. Note that the NTP protocol did not originally specify a large enough field to represent IPv6 addresses, so they use the first four bytes of the MD5 hash of the reference clock's IPv6 address (i.e. an IPv4 address here is not necessarily IPv4).

zeek.smtp_msg_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

These are the contents of the MsgID header.

zeek.smtp_path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

The message transmission path, as extracted from the headers.

zeek.smtp_rcptto.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

These are the email addresses found in the RCPT TO header.

zeek.smtp_subject.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

These are the contents of the Subject header.

zeek.smtp_trans_depth.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

A count to represent the depth of this message transaction in a single connection where multiple messages were transferred.

zeek.smtp_user_agent.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the value of the User-Agent header from the client.

zeek.snmp_duration.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The amount of time between the first packet beloning to the SNMP session and the latest one seen.

zeek.snmp_get_bulk_requests.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The number of variable bindings in GetBulkRequest PDUs seen for the session.

zeek.snmp_get_requests.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The number of variable bindings in GetRequest/GetNextRequest PDUs seen for the session.

zeek.snmp_get_responses.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The number of variable bindings in GetResponse/Response PDUs seen for the session.

zeek.snmp_set_requests.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The number of variable bindings in SetRequest PDUs seen for the session.

zeek.snmp_up_since.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date

The time at which the SNMP responder endpoint claims it's been up since.

zeek.snmp_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the version of SNMP being used.

zeek.socks_bound_host.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Server bound address. Could be an address, a name or both.

zeek.socks_bound_p.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the server bound port.

zeek.socks_request_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Client requested SOCKS address. Could be an address, a name or both.

zeek.socks_request_p.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the client requested port.

zeek.socks_status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the server status for the attempt at using the proxy.

zeek.socks_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the protocol version of SOCKS.

zeek.software_host.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip

The IP address detected running the software.

zeek.software_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the name of the software (e.g. Apache).

zeek.software_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the type of software detected.

zeek.software_unparsed_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the full unparsed version of the software.

zeek.software_version_addl.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This field contains additional version information.

zeek.software_version_major.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the major version of software.

zeek.software_version_minor.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the minor version of software.

zeek.software_version_minor2.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the 2nd minor version of software.

zeek.software_version_minor3.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the 3rd minor version of software.

zeek.ssh_auth_attempts.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

The number of authentication attempts we observed. There's always at least one, since some servers might support no authentication at all. It's important to note that not all of these are failures, since some servers require two-factor auth (e.g. password AND pubkey).

zeek.ssh_auth_success.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean

Authentication result (T=success, F=failure, unset=unknown).

zeek.ssh_cipher_alg.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the encryption algorithm in use.

zeek.ssh_client.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the client's version string.

zeek.ssh_compression_alg.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the compression algorithm in use.

zeek.ssh_direction.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

Direction of the connection. If the client was a local host logging into an external host, this would be OUTBOUND. INBOUND would be set for the opposite situation.

zeek.ssh_host_key.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the server's key thumbprint.

zeek.ssh_host_key_alg.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the server host key's algorithm.

zeek.ssh_kex_alg.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the key exchange algorithm in use.

zeek.ssh_mac_alg.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the signing (MAC) algorithm in use.

zeek.ssh_server.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the server's version string.

zeek.ssh_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long

This is the SSH major version (1 or 2).

zeek.ssl_cert_chain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the chain of certificates offered by the server to validate its complete signing chain.

zeek.ssl_cert_chain_fuids.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is an ordered vector of certificate file identifiers for the certificates offered by the server.

zeek.ssl_client_cert_chain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the chain of certificates offered by the client to validate its complete signing chain.

zeek.ssl_client_cert_chain_fuids.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is an ordered vector of certificate file identifiers for the certificates offered by the client.

zeek.ssl_client_issuer.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the issuer of the client's SSL certificate.

zeek.ssl_client_subject.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the subject of the client's SSL certificate.

zeek.ssl_issuer.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the issuer of the server's SSL certificate.

zeek.ssl_server_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the value of the Server Name Indicator SSL/TLS extension. It indicates the server name that the client was requesting.

zeek.ssl_subject.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the subject of the server's SSL certificate.

zeek.ssl_validation_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the result of certificate validation for this connection, given as OpenSSL validation code.

zeek.ssl_validation_status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the result of certificate validation for this connection.

zeek.ssl_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword

This is the SSL/TLS version that was logged.

This is the number of DNS requests.

_normalizeBlock.description: Normalization block. Valid formats: (1) map, (2) check+map, (3) check+parse|+map, (4) check+parse|, (5) parse-only

oneOf.description: Must include at least one key parse|<field>: [...]. 'map' is not allowed.
Must include at least one key parse|<field>: [...].

_parse.description: List of parser expressions (e.g., logpar). Evaluated in order until one succeeds.

definitions.description: Build-time typed macros expanded by interpolation. Conflicts, precedence, chaining, and scope are enforced at build time.

enabled.description: Whether the decoder is enabled or disabled

id.description: Unique identifier for the decoder in UUIDv4 format

modified.description: Last modification date in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD)

name.description: Component name with 3 parts: decoder/<name>/<version>

parents.description: Parent decoders evaluated before this one
